In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Bangladesh asked the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for policy 
and advisory technical assistance (TA) to prepare the Strategic Master Plan for Chittagong Port. 
ADB approved the TA concept paper on 8 July 2011. In April 2011, an ADB fact-finding mission 
held discussions with the Ministry of Shipping, the Chittagong Port Authority, and the Economic 
Relations  Division  of the  Ministry  of  Finance  to  prepare  the TA. The  mission  reached  an 
understanding with the government on the TA project's impact, outcome, scope, implementation 
arrangements, and terms of reference.1 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Chittagong Port is the principal seaport of Bangladesh and handles about 92% of the 
country's import–export trade. As such its importance to the national economy is paramount. In 
the fiscal year (FY) 2009/10, Chittagong Port handled about 30.5 million tons of cargo and about 
1.21 million 20-foot equivalent container units. The annual growth rate for 20-foot equivalent 
container units handled has been 9.4% in the FY 2009/10. Inefficient port operations and 
inadequate  intermodal  connectivity  are  principal  issues  in  Bangladesh's  transport  sector. 
Inefficient  port  operations  result  in  congestion  in  cargo  handling  and  clearance.  Weak 
intermodal connectivity results in prolonged waiting time and occupies space for exchanging 
cargoes, and higher overall transport costs due to limited availability of transportation modes, 
which discourages potential economic activities and external trade. 
 
3.  Chittagong Port is a river port situated mainly on the northern bank of Karnaphuli River 
about 16 kilometers (km) upstream from the Bay of Bengal. The width, curvature, and draft of 
the river limit the size of vessels able to call at Chittagong Port, and increasing siltation in recent 
years is threatening to limit further the growth in transport through Chittagong Port. The port is in 
the south of the city of Chittagong, the second largest city in Bangladesh and about 250 km 
southeast of Dhaka, the nation’s capital and administrative and economic center.  
 
4.  Chittagong Port will increase its container-handling capacity in coming years, once the 
new mooring container terminal is fully operational. The terminal is located directly west of the 
existing facilities of Chittagong Container Terminal and will be managed by a private operator 
under a public–private partnership scheme. Expansion of the port on the northern bank of 
Karnaphuli River is constrained by the city; in particular, road and rail traffic bound for the port 
has to pass through the city of Chittagong. Land for port expansion is available on the southern 
bank of Karnaphuli River, but connectivity to these areas is poor and the consequences of 
developing port facilities on siltation need to be studied. 
 
5.  Dhaka and Chittagong are linked by air, inland waterways, roads, and railway. Road and 
railway traffic between Dhaka and Chittagong Port is facing serious capacity bottlenecks. The 
327 km railway between Dhaka and Chittagong is partially a single-track line, which limits the 
number  of  daily  trains.  Due to the  preference given  to  passenger transportation,  only  4-5 
container trains per day are operating between Dhaka and Chittagong, carrying around 10% of 
the containers to and from Chittagong Port. The railway capacity will improve in 3-5 years, when 
most of the single-track sections have been converted into double track. These projects are 
financed by ADB, India, and the Japan International Cooperation Agency. Once the upgrade of 
the Dhaka–Chittagong railway is completed, establishing an integrated multimodal transport

2   
chain between Dhaka and Chittagong Port is essential, including inland container depots for 
transshipment of containers between road feeder transport, railway, and port.  
 
6.  The road traffic between Dhaka and Chittagong is hampered by the lack of capacity of 
the 250 km highway and by load restrictions on bridges. In general, fully loaded containers 
cannot be transported to Dhaka by road, so loading and unloading of containers takes place in 
Chittagong Port. Widening of the two-lane highway between Dhaka and Chittagong to four lanes 
is ongoing, and the government plans to realize an expressway between Dhaka and Chittagong 
under a private–public partnership. Once these improvements for road transport to Chittagong 
Port  are  realized,  the  port  will  need  upgraded  facilities  with  more  capacity  to  handle  the 
additional traffic and to store containers. 
 
7.  Inland waterways are used to transport bulk and general cargo to Chittagong Port. It is 
planned to use inland waterways also for container transport between Dhaka and Chittagong 
Port, and a river port to handle containers near Dhaka is under construction.  
 
8.  Air transport between Dhaka and Chittagong caters mainly to passenger transport. The 
number of flights is limited and flights are not used for hinterland transport to Chittagong Port. 
 
9.  Recent high-level intergovernmental consultations and agreements will allow improved 
access  for  Bhutan,  India,  and  Nepal  to  Chittagong  Port.  This  additional  traffic  has  to  be 
considered when designing new facilities at Chittagong Port, as this will not only create more 
traffic, but will also require additional port facilities to cater for transit traffic. 
 
10.  Supporting  the  development  of  Chittagong  Port  and  improving  integrated  landside 
hinterland transport to reduce trade logistic costs for transport services are key objectives of the 
transport  policies  outlined  in  the  government’s  Sixth  Five-Year  Plan  (2011–2015).  The 
government further recognized the importance of integrated intermodal systems under the draft 
Integrated Multimodal Transport Policy. Port development provides significant opportunities for 
improvement of intermodal transport systems and logistics services, hence boosting efficiency 
of economic activities. Port development also provides opportunities for expansion of regional 
trade with Bhutan, India, and Nepal.  
 
11.  All previous development plans for Chittagong Port are outdated (the latest Chittagong 
Port master plan covers the period 1995–2010) and do not consider the recent upgrades of 
maritime and landside infrastructure, and improvements in port efficiency, e.g., through the 
recently introduced container terminal management system or the opening of Chittagong Port to 
transit traffic. Apart from coping with rising demand, there is an urgent need for expansion of 
port facilities to cope with rising demand and provide specialized facilities for bulk cargo; private 
investors are approaching Chittagong Port Authority for permission to develop new port facilities 
such as jetties, new port basins, and warehouses.  
 
12.  To address these ongoing and anticipated developments in demand for and in access to 
the port, and to ensure continuous sustainable growth for Bangladesh’s economy, a new master 
plan for strategic development of Chittagong Port shall be prepared, providing a long-term vision 
for the development of the port with a planning horizon of 25-30 years. Improving the overall 
capacity of Chittagong Port will help to maintain sustainable economic growth in Bangladesh by 
ensuring access to international markets. This has a direct impact on poverty reduction in 
Bangladesh by providing employment opportunities during design, construction, and operation 
and maintenance of the port facilities, in activities related to trade and trade facilitation, in the 
transport sector, and in export-oriented industrial production.

3 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
13.  The impact of the TA will be improved efficiency of port operations and intermodal 
transport  logistics  to  support  sustainable  economic  growth  in  Bangladesh,  and  regional 
connectivity for landlocked Bhutan and Nepal, and the northeastern states of India.   
 
14.  The outcome of the TA will be an agreed overall framework for port development under 
possible development scenarios and will support the integrated intermodal port development on 
both the maritime and land side of the port based on an updated traffic forecast.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
15.  The TA will support preparation of a strategic port master plan—including (i) preparation 
of a comprehensive traffic and development forecast for Chittagong Port in different scenarios 
based on the anticipated social and economic development for Bangladesh; trade with third 
countries and the expected demand for transit to Bhutan, India, and Nepal; (ii) assessment of 
the  port's  infrastructure  and  intermodal  connectivity  with  the  road  and  rail  network  linking 
Chittagong Port to major sources of demand in Bangladesh and the region; (iii) assessment of 
the hydraulic conditions in Karnaphuli River to propose sustainable port development; and 
(iv) updating of the overall port development framework for Chittagong Port development based 
on recent infrastructure development and the traffic forecasts prepared under item (i)—and 
recommend integrated multimodal maritime and landside development scenarios for sustainable 
development of the port as the major regional and international trade gateway for Bangladesh 
and the northeastern South Asia region. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The Government has requested ADB to finance  $1,000,000 equivalent. The TA will be 
financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and administered by ADB. 
The government will provide counterpart support in the form of office accommodation, support 
facilities, counterpart staff, maps, reports, and other logistical support and will finance a detailed 
hydraulic, hydrological, and geo-morphological study on Karnaphuli River. The cost estimates 
and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  The executing agency is the Ministry of Shipping, which will chair a steering committee 
to provide overall guidance on TA delivery. The implementing agency is the Chittagong Port 
Authority, which will be the major point of contact for the TA consultants and will interact with 
them on a day-to-day basis.  
 
18.  The TA will be implemented from May 2012 to December 2014. Consulting services will 
be carried out over a period of 24 months by a firm of consultants comprising experts in 
transport  planning,  transport  policy  and  institutions,  transport  economics,  ports  and  river 
hydraulics,  dredging,  traffic  engineering  and  modeling,  information  technology  systems, 
customs and trade facilitation, roads and railway transport, multimodal transport, land and aerial 
surveying, ports and river engineering, and coastal morphology. About 27 person-months of 
international consulting and about 32 person-months of national consulting will be provided. 
ADB will engage the consultants in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants

4   
(2010, as amended from time to time) using the quality- and cost-based selection with a quality-
cost ratio of 90:10. This quality-cost ratio is proposed in light of the high complexity of the scope 
of works, which requires specialized inputs from qualified consultants with experience in the 
fields of maritime design and transport, traffic forecasting and traffic modeling, and multimodal 
transport; and the services have to be carried out in a mixed team of international and national 
consultants within a tight timeframe. The consultants will submit simplified technical proposals. 
The outline terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3.  
 
19.  All equipment for the TA will be procured according to ADB’s Procurement Guidelines 
(2010, as amended from time to time) and transferred to the government upon TA completion. 
Disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with ADB's Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
20.  The  consultants  will  submit  (i)  an  inception  report  within  4  weeks  of  starting  their 
services, detailing the initial work program and the terms of reference for the detailed hydraulic 
and hydrologic study for Karnaphuli River; (ii) two interim reports 6 and 12 months after starting 
their services, including the overall development framework for Chittagong Port development; 
(iii) the draft final report after 21 months of services; and (iv) the final report on TA completion, 
incorporating comments by the government and ADB, to be completed 2 weeks after receipt of 
the comments. The consultants will also submit monthly progress reports with a summary of 
activities and recommendations for action on issues. 
 
21.  Two national workshops will be conducted during TA implementation. The first, with all 
relevant stakeholders involved in business with and trade through Chittagong Port, will discuss 
the objective, approach, and methodology to establish the master plan for Chittagong Port and 
collect inputs from these stakeholders. The first workshop shall be held within 1-2 months from 
the start of consulting services. The second workshop will discuss TA outputs for finalization 
after submission of the draft final report. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $1,000,000  to  the 
Government of Bangladesh to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty 
Reduction for the Strategic Master Plan for Chittagong Port, and hereby reports this action to 
the Board.

8     Appendix 3        
   
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
A.  Scope 
1.  The  policy  and  advisory  technical  assistance  (TA)  administered  by  the  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  is  to  prepare  a  strategic  master  plan  for  the  development  of 
Chittagong Port. The TA will also identify potential future projects for public and private sector 
funding, including projects for possible ADB financing.  
 
2.  The  consultants  will  conduct  a  study  to  assess  the  characteristics  of  existing  port 
operations, and of existing and planned maritime and landside infrastructure, and prepare the 
overall  port  development  framework.  The  Consultant  shall  support  the  government  and 
Chittagong Port authority (CPA) in recruiting a consulting firm to carry out a detailed hydraulic, 
hydrological and geo-morphological study of the Karnaphuli River, supervise the progress of this 
study and incorporate the recommendations of the study into the strategic master plan for 
Chittagong  Port;  this  study  will  be  carried  out  under  a  separate  contract  funded  by  the 
government. The consultants will carry out the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Traffic forecast for Chittagong Port 
 
(a) Undertake an analysis of traffic demand for the port and its modal split distributions 
for hinterland transport from the port to major origins/destinations of the shipments in 
Bangladesh, and for regional connectivity, by utilizing existing data and studies, and 
conducting a traffic data survey with current and potential clients of the port and 
other stakeholders as required to supplement and update existing data. 
(b) Plan and carry out necessary additional traffic surveys and analysis. 
(c) Prepare a traffic forecast based on different scenarios for the economic development. 
 
(ii)  Assessment of infrastructure in the port and intermodal connectivity 
 
(a) Study the situation of maritime and landside infrastructure, including ongoing and 
planned projects, considering the probability of these projects being realized. 
(b) Study  major modes  of hinterland  transport  and  their  potential  role for  access to 
Chittagong Port, especially road, rail, and inland waterways, to identify barriers to 
intermodal  connectivity  at  the  port  and  at  possible  origins/destinations  of  the 
shipments. 
(c) Suggest physical and operational efficiency improvements and propose alternative 
measures to remove barriers for intermodal connectivity. 
(d) Review operation and maintenance of the port and equipment used and suggest 
improvements where needed.  
(e) Identify  needs for  improvements  of  the navigability  in  the  Bay  of  Bengal,  in  the 
channel of Karnaphuli River, and alongside berths and jetties. 
(f)  Study different options to improve Chittagong Port facilities with additional jetties or 
new docking and/or holding basins also on the southern bank of Karnaphuli River.

Appendix 3  9 
(g) Prepare preliminary cost estimates for various improvement measures and assess 
the economic viability. 
(h) Review  operational  performance  and  identify  possible  cost  and  efficiency 
improvements along with necessary key actions. 
(i)  Undertake  a  preliminary  environmental  assessment,  social  assessment,  and 
assessment of the potential need for land acquisition and resettlement. 
(j)  Review the port security system and provide suggestions for improvements, if any. 
(k) Assess the institutional and governance capacity of the Chittagong Port Authority and 
provide  specific  recommendations  on  substantial  institutional  improvements  and 
capacity development. 
 
(iii)  Detailed hydraulic and hydrologic study for Karnaphuli River 
 
(a) Draft  the  terms  of  reference  for  a  detailed  hydraulic,  hydrological,  and  geo-
morphological study on Karnaphuli River (from the Bay of Bengal to 10 kilometers 
upstream of Chittagong Port) to identify possible locations for potential port projects. 
(b) Support the government and CPA in recruiting a consultant to carry out the detailed 
hydraulic, hydrological and geo-morphological study on Karnaphuli River, supervise 
the  consultant  during  the  implementation  of  the  study,  review  the  approach, 
methodology, progress and interim reports as well as the draft final and final reports 
and incorporate the findings into the strategic master plan for Chittagong Port. 
(c) Study and propose together with the consultant carrying out the detailed hydraulic, 
hydrological and geo-morphological study on Karnaphuli River long-term sustainable 
river training work to reduce siltation in the port area and the port’s access channel to 
identify possible locations for future port expansion.  
(d) Define together with the consultant carrying out the detailed hydraulic, hydrological 
and geo-morphological study on Karnaphuli River the scope for studies to prepare 
interventions for river training work or other siltation mitigation measures that would 
ensure long-term sustainability of investments in Chittagong Port. 
 
(iv)  Overall port development framework and strategic master plan 
 
(a) Prepare a strategic master plan for Chittagong Port development in the next 25 to 
30 years with inputs from the evaluation of the above studies, such as traffic demand, 
technical feasibility, hinterland access, navigability, economic and financial viability, 
environment, and social and resettlement aspects.  
(b) Prepare a phased plan for port development based on different scenarios for port 
development. 
(c) Establish a land use plan for the port, access to the port, and related auxiliary 
facilities that cater for the overall port development.

10  Appendix 3 
 
 
(d) Review  manpower  requirements,  and  occupational  health  and  safety  measures 
based on different development scenarios and suggest improvements.  
(e) Assess the need for legal reforms covering rules,manuals, and others as required. 
(f)  Recommend  projects  to  be  implemented  with  possible  external  financing  from 
development partners or potential financing by the private sector. 
(g) Propose  alternative  financing  schemes  for  effective  utilization  of  private  sector 
financing  and/or  management  expertise,  and  identify  the  need  for  further  study 
and/or support for implementation. 
 
B.  Schedule and Staff Requirements  
 
3.  The consulting services will be completed in 24 months, from May 2012 to April 2014. A 
firm  of  consultants  will  be  engaged  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The consultants shall be selected using 
ADB’s quality- and cost-based selection method with a quality-cost ratio of 90:10.

services, detailing the initial work program and the terms of reference for the detailed hydraulic

final report on TA completion, incorporating comments by the government and ADB, to be 
completed 2 weeks after receipt of the comments. The consultants will also submit monthly 
progress reports with a summary of activities and recommendations for action on issues.
